abstract: The nation’s largest banks will face stress tests this week, as the government examines their viability.
snippet: The nation’s largest banks will face stress tests this week, as the government examines their viability.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration will begin taking a hard look at the financial condition of the country’s 20 biggest banks this week to judge whether they could hold up even if the downturn worsens further than policy makers already expect.

headline.main: As Doubts Grow, U.S. Will Judge Banks’ Stability
headline.print_headline: As Doubts Grow, U.S. Will Judge Banks’ Stability

abstract: Bank stocks plunged last week on fears that the government would have to take over battered institutions like Citigroup and Bank of America. That would wipe out the banks’ shareholders — hence, investors’ rush for the exits — and put the government in control of a swath of the financial system.
lead_paragraph: Bank stocks plunged last week on fears that the government would have to take over battered institutions like Citigroup and Bank of America. That would wipe out the banks’ shareholders — hence, investors’ rush for the exits — and put the government in control of a swath of the financial system.

abstract: Shares in Citigroup and Bank of America rose on Monday after the federal government offered measured words of reassurance on its support of the nation’s big banks.
lead_paragraph: Shares in Citigroup and Bank of America rose on Monday after the federal government offered measured words of reassurance on its support of the nation’s big banks.

headline.main: Bank Stocks Rise on U.S. Comments

abstract: Merrill Lynch‘s former chief executive, John A. Thain, was questioned by the New York State Attorney General’s Office last week. In a six-hour session, Mr. Thain answered wide-ranging questions about the bonuses he paid Merrill employees and about his interactions with officials at Bank of America, which acquired Merrill at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Merrill Lynch‘s former chief executive, John A. Thain, was questioned by the New York State Attorney General’s Office last week. In a six-hour session, Mr. Thain answered wide-ranging questions about the bonuses he paid Merrill employees and about his interactions with officials at Bank of America, which acquired Merrill at the end of the year.

headline.main: A Look at Cuomo’s Questions for Thain
